moves.1. d4 e5: Englund Gambit.  I have not played against this before.  According to Wikipedia, the idea is for Black to move into a tactical game and away from the closed d4 openings.  I thought the game definitely had more of an e4 character, so I think it succeeded at that.
moves.2. dxe5 d6 3. exd6 Bxd6: Black is down a pawn, but has an extra tempo to compensate.
moves.4. Nf3 Nf6 5. Nc3 c6: I think maybe Bd7 or a6 was better here if the goal is to keep White's N off b5.  c6 takes away a good square for the N.
moves.6. e4 O-O: Black puts the extra tempo to good use here.
moves.7. Bd3 Re8 8. O-O Bg4 9. h3 Bh5 10. Be3: I'm not sure if this is the best square for the B.  g5 may be a better option.
moves.10... h6 11. Re1 Qe7 12. Bd4 Bc7 13. Bxf: This is definitely not smart.  It gives Black too much pressure of f3.
moves.13... Qxf6 14. g4 Bxg4 15. hxg4 Qf4: Black sacrifices the B to open White's K.  White needs to get reinforcements to the Kingside as quickly as possible.
moves.16. Bf1 Na6: This awkward development is required because c6 is blocked.
moves.17. Bg2 Nc5 18. Qd2 Qxg4 19. Qe3 Bf4: I think this was an oversight.  Black was thinking about his attack and didn't notice his N was hanging.
moves.20. Qxc5 Re6 21. Qf5: This forces the exchange of Qs.  If White can defuse the Kingside attack, the position should be won easily.
Black is down to two Rs.
moves.25. Rad1 Re6: Black avoids Rxe4.  It will lead to further exchanges and a loss of material after 25...Rxe4  26. Rxe4 Rxe4  27. Rd8+ Kh7  28. Ng5+ hxg5  29. Bxe4.
moves.27... Rxf3 28. Rxg6 fxg6 29. Bxf3: White's material advantage is now decisive.
moves.32... Kd7: Black resigned here.  White's biggest problem will be figuring out the most efficient checkmate.  There is no chance to lose this position now.
